res: Let $E$ be a Euclidean space of at most three dimensions. If $A$ is a nonempty subset of $E$, define $S(A)$ to be the set of all points that lie on closed segments joining pairs of points of $A$. For a given nonempty set $A_0$, define $A_n=S(A_{n-1})$ for $n=1,2,\dots$. Prove that $A_2=A_3=\cdots$. (A one-point set should be considered to be a special case of a closed segment.)

Translating: Let $E$ be a Euclidean space of at most three dimensions. If $A$ is a nonempty subset of $E$, define $S(A)$ to be the set of all points that lie on closed segments joining pairs of points of $A$. For a given nonempty set $A_0$, define $A_n=S(A_{n-1})$ for $n=1,2,\dots$. Prove that $A_2=A_3=\cdots$. (A one-point set should be considered to be a special case of a closed segment.)

res.content: You are a Mathematics, Lean 4 and coding assistant who answers questions about Mathematics and Lean 4, gives hints while coding in Lean 4. You also translates from natural language to Lean Theorem Prover code and vice versa when asked. Follow EXACTLY any examples given when generating Lean code.

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: The span of a set of points is contained in a subspace if and only if the set of points is
contained in the subspace. 

Give ONLY the Lean code

âˆ€ {K : Type u_1} {V : Type u_2} [inst : Field K] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup V] [inst_2 : Module K V]
  {S : Set (Projectivization K V)} {W : Projectivization.Subspace K V}, Projectivization.Subspace.span S â‰¤ W â†” S âŠ† â†‘W

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Definition: The span of a set of points in projective space is a subspace. 

Give ONLY the Lean code

{K : Type u_1} â†’
  {V : Type u_2} â†’
    [inst : Field K] â†’
      [inst_1 : AddCommGroup V] â†’ [inst_2 : Module K V] â†’ Set (Projectivization K V) â†’ Projectivization.Subspace K V

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: In a sequential space, a sequentially closed set is closed. 

Give ONLY the Lean code
âˆ€ {X : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : SequentialSpace X] {s : Set X}, IsSeqClosed s â†’ IsClosed s

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: A closed subset of a compact set is a compact set. 

Give ONLY the Lean code
âˆ€ {X : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] {s t : Set X}, IsCompact s â†’ IsClosed t â†’ t âŠ† s â†’ IsCompact t

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem:  In a two-dimensional subspace, if three points have the same distances to two distinct points, then the three points are collinear and lie on a segment connecting the two distinct points.

Give ONLY the Lean code

âˆ€ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace â„ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] {s : AffineSubspace â„ P} [inst_4 : FiniteDimensional â„ â†¥s.direction],
  FiniteDimensional.finrank â„ â†¥s.direction = 2 â†’
    âˆ€ {câ‚ câ‚‚ pâ‚ pâ‚‚ p : P},
      câ‚ âˆˆ s â†’
        câ‚‚ âˆˆ s â†’
          pâ‚ âˆˆ s â†’
            pâ‚‚ âˆˆ s â†’
              p âˆˆ s â†’
                âˆ€ {râ‚ râ‚‚ : â„},
                  câ‚ â‰  câ‚‚ â†’
                    pâ‚ â‰  pâ‚‚ â†’
                      dist pâ‚ câ‚ = râ‚ â†’
                        dist pâ‚‚ câ‚ = râ‚ â†’
                          dist p câ‚ = râ‚ â†’ dist pâ‚ câ‚‚ = râ‚‚ â†’ dist pâ‚‚ câ‚‚ = râ‚‚ â†’ dist p câ‚‚ = râ‚‚ â†’ p = pâ‚ âˆ¨ p = pâ‚‚

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: A compact set in an emetric space is separable, i.e., it is the closure of a countable set. 

Give ONLY the Lean code
âˆ€ {Î³ : Type w} [inst : EMetricSpace Î³] {s : Set Î³}, IsCompact s â†’ âˆƒ t âŠ† s, Set.Countable t âˆ§ s = closure t

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: This theorem states that for any type `Î±` equipped with an Emetric space structure, if `s` is a closed subset of `Î±`, then the collection of all subsets of `s` also forms a closed set. In mathematical terms, if `s` is a closed set in the Emetric space `Î±`, then the set `{t | t âŠ† s}` is also closed. Here, `{t | t âŠ† s}` denotes the set of all subsets `t` of `s`.

Give ONLY the Lean code
âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} [inst : EMetricSpace Î±] {s : Set Î±}, IsClosed s â†’ IsClosed {t | â†‘t âŠ† s}

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem:  Given a nonempty n-dimensional subspace s in a Euclidean space and a set of n+1 points in s that are equidistant from a point, all n-simplices formed by these points have the same circumradius.

Give ONLY the Lean code

âˆ€ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace â„ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] {s : AffineSubspace â„ P} {ps : Set P},
  ps âŠ† â†‘s â†’
    âˆ€ [inst_4 : Nonempty â†¥s] {n : â„•} [inst_5 : FiniteDimensional â„ â†¥s.direction],
      FiniteDimensional.finrank â„ â†¥s.direction = n â†’
        EuclideanGeometry.Cospherical ps â†’
          âˆƒ r, âˆ€ (sx : Affine.Simplex â„ P n), Set.range sx.points âŠ† ps â†’ sx.circumradius = r

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: In a sequential space, a set is closed iff it's sequentially closed. 

Give ONLY the Lean code
âˆ€ {X : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : SequentialSpace X] {M : Set X}, IsSeqClosed M â†” IsClosed M

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: The theorem states that for a metric space of points equipped with a real inner product space and a torsor structure over the normed add commutative group, if four points `A`, `B`, `C`, `D` are cospherical (i.e., they are all equidistant from some common point), and another point `P` lies on the lines `AB` and `CD` (with certain non-trivial scaling factors), then the product of the Euclidean distances from `P` to `A` and `B` equals the product of the Euclidean distances from `P` to `C` and `D`.

Give ONLY the Lean code

âˆ€ {V : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace â„ V] {P : Type u_2} [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] {a b c d p : P},
  EuclideanGeometry.Cospherical {a, b, c, d} â†’
    (âˆƒ kâ‚, kâ‚ â‰  1 âˆ§ b -áµ¥ p = kâ‚ â€¢ (a -áµ¥ p)) â†’
      (âˆƒ kâ‚‚, kâ‚‚ â‰  1 âˆ§ d -áµ¥ p = kâ‚‚ â€¢ (c -áµ¥ p)) â†’ dist a p * dist b p = dist c p * dist d p

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem:  In a 2-dimensional Euclidean space with finite dimension over the real numbers, if two distinct spheres each contain three distinct points, then at least two of those points are identical.

Give ONLY the Lean code

âˆ€ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace â„ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [inst_4 : FiniteDimensional â„ V],
  FiniteDimensional.finrank â„ V = 2 â†’
    âˆ€ {sâ‚ sâ‚‚ : EuclideanGeometry.Sphere P} {pâ‚ pâ‚‚ p : P},
      sâ‚ â‰  sâ‚‚ â†’ pâ‚ â‰  pâ‚‚ â†’ pâ‚ âˆˆ sâ‚ â†’ pâ‚‚ âˆˆ sâ‚ â†’ p âˆˆ sâ‚ â†’ pâ‚ âˆˆ sâ‚‚ â†’ pâ‚‚ âˆˆ sâ‚‚ â†’ p âˆˆ sâ‚‚ â†’ p = pâ‚ âˆ¨ p = pâ‚‚

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: Subsets of a given closed subset form a closed set 

Give ONLY the Lean code
âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} [inst : EMetricSpace Î±] {s : Set Î±}, IsClosed s â†’ IsClosed {t | â†‘t âŠ† s}

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: This theorem states that for a set of points in an affine space, if the set is collinear, then the affine span of any two distinct points from this set is equal to the affine span of the entire set. In other words, if a set of points all lie on a single line, then the subspace generated by any two distinct points from the set is the same as the subspace generated by the entire set.

Give ONLY the Lean code

âˆ€ {k : Type u_1} {V : Type u_2} {P : Type u_3} [inst : DivisionRing k] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup V] [inst_2 : Module k V]
  [inst_3 : AddTorsor V P] {s : Set P},
  Collinear k s â†’ âˆ€ {pâ‚ pâ‚‚ : P}, pâ‚ âˆˆ s â†’ pâ‚‚ âˆˆ s â†’ pâ‚ â‰  pâ‚‚ â†’ affineSpan k {pâ‚, pâ‚‚} = affineSpan k s

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem:  If $(S\_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ is a sequence of non-empty, complete, closed, and bounded sets in a pseudo-metric space, such that the diameter of $S\_n$ tends to 0 and the intersection of any finite subsequence is non-empty, then $\bigcap\_{n \in \mathbb{N}} S\_n$ is non-empty.

Give ONLY the Lean code

âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} [inst : PseudoMetricSpace Î±] {s : â„• â†’ Set Î±},
  IsComplete (s 0) â†’
    (âˆ€ (n : â„•), IsClosed (s n)) â†’
      (âˆ€ (n : â„•), Bornology.IsBounded (s n)) â†’
        (âˆ€ (N : â„•), (â‹‚ n, â‹‚ (_ : n â‰¤ N), s n).Nonempty) â†’
          Filter.Tendsto (fun n => Metric.diam (s n)) Filter.atTop (nhds 0) â†’ (â‹‚ n, s n).Nonempty

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: A finite-dimensional subspace is closed. 

Give ONLY the Lean code

âˆ€ {ğ•œ : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} [inst : NontriviallyNormedField ğ•œ] [inst_1 : CompleteSpace ğ•œ] [inst_2 : AddCommGroup E]
  [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace E] [inst_4 : T2Space E] [inst_5 : TopologicalAddGroup E] [inst_6 : Module ğ•œ E]
  [inst_7 : ContinuousSMul ğ•œ E] (s : Submodule ğ•œ E) [inst_8 : FiniteDimensional ğ•œ â†¥s], IsClosed â†‘s

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: Let $E$ be a Euclidean space of at most three dimensions. If $A$ is a nonempty subset of $E$, define $S(A)$ to be the set of all points that lie on closed segments joining pairs of points of $A$. For a given nonempty set $A_0$, define $A_n=S(A_{n-1})$ for $n=1,2,\dots$. Prove that $A_2=A_3=\cdots$. (A one-point set should be considered to be a special case of a closed segment.)

Give ONLY the Lean code
